questions.text: All of the following are poor prognostic variables in endometrial cancer, except:

A 48 y/o woman has had irregular and postcoital vaginal bleeding for 3 months. Pelvic exam reveals a 3-cm exophytic cervical lesion. Biopsy shows squamous cell carcinoma. Imaging confirms the tumor is confined to the cervix with no parametrial or lymph node involvement. She has a h/o DVT and on anticoagulants. What is the most appropriate treatment option for her?
questions.explanation:
Management of cervical cancer

Stage

Management

Radiotherapy (Brachytherapy, Teletherapy)

Chemoradiation

IA1

Conization or extra fascial hysterectomy (if childbirth is completed) (Option C)

Intracavitary brachytherapy alone (not surgical candidates).

NIL

IA2

Radical hysterectomy or radical trachelectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy.

  

IB1

Radical hysterectomy or radical trachelectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy.

NIL

Chemoradiation.

IB2

Radical hysterectomy

IB3

Chemoradiation

IIA1

Radical hysterectomy or chemoradiation.

IIA2

Chemoradiation

IIB-IVA

Chemoradiation and pelvic exenteration for central recurrences after radiotherapy.

External beam radiation therapy (40 to 50 Gy) for 5 weeks.

Brachytherapy (post ext. Beam radiation.

Concurrent chemotherapy, with cisplatin.

IVB

Palliative; pelvic radiation to manage symptoms.

Pelvic radiation (symptom control)

Systemic chemotherapy

questions.text: A 32 y/o female presents with irregular vaginal bleeding and post-coital bleeding for the past 3 months. Pelvic examination reveals a 2 cm ulcerative lesion on the cervix. Biopsy confirms the diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix. The patient is deeply concerned about preserving her fertility. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.correct_answer: C. Radical trachelectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy
questions.explanation:
Stage

Surgical Management

Post-Surgical Management

IA1
  • Simple hysterectomy (Type I).
  • Conization if family not complete

Regular pelvic exams and Pap smears.

IA1 (with LVSI)
  • Modified radical hysterectomy (Type II) + pelvic lymphadenectomy (PLND).
  • Radical trachelectomy + PLND (consider SNLB) for selected patients desiring fertility

IA2
  • Radical hysterectomy + PLND (consider SNLB if tumor <2 cm).
  • Radical trachelectomy + PLND for selected patients desiring fertility.
  • If the specimen shows high-risk features - Adjuvant chemoradiation.
  • Regular pelvic exams and Pap smears.

IB1
  • Radical hysterectomy + PLND (consider SNLB if tumor <2 cm).
  • Radical trachelectomy + PLND for selected patients desiring fertility.

IB2

Radical hysterectomy + PLND

IIA1

IB3 - IIA2

Chemoradiation

Regular pelvic exams and Pap smears

IIB - IVA

Chemoradiation

IVB

Palliative chemotherapy and/or Palliative radiotherapy

questions.text: A 42 Y/o woman presents with a history of irregular vaginal bleeding and postcoital spotting. She has not had a Pap smear in over five years. On physical examination, the cervix appears abnormal, and a biopsy confirms cervical carcinoma. Which of the following is the most common histological type of cervical cancer?
questions.explanation:
Squamous Cell Carcinoma (Option B)

Adenocarcinoma (Option A)

Most common histological type of cervical cancer.

2nd most common histological type of cervical cancer.

Commonly arises from transformation zone

Commonly arises from endocervical mucus producing columnar cells.

Further divided into three types:

  • Keratinizing
  • Nonkeratinizing
  • Papillary

Further divided into:

  • Mucinous (most common subtype)
  • Endometrioid
  • Serous
  • Clear cell
  • Mesonephric.

Histology: Nests of malignant squamous cells with brisk lymphocytic response and keratin pearls at center.

 

Histology: Columnar, relatively mucin poor cells with stratified atypical nuclei and brisk mitotic activity. Chronic inflammation may be present (asterisk)

questions.text: A 28-year-old nulliparous woman has been diagnosed with persistent CIN 1 for 2 years after initial observation and monitoring. Colposcopy reveals no high-grade lesions, and the entire lesion and squamocolumnar junction (SCJ) are fully visible. Which treatment option is most appropriate in this case?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ CIN 1 persisting over 2 years with entire lesion and SCJ visible, no HSIL in endocervical sampling: Preferred treatment is cryoablation.
  • ↳ If above criteria not met (lesion visibility, HSIL absence): Excisional treatment is recommended; ablation is not suitable. (Option C)
  • ↳ If above criteria not met (lesion visibility, HSIL absence):
  • ↳ (Option C)
  • ↳ Persistent LSIL may warrant treatment.
  • ↳ Patient factors (compliance, preference) may influence treatment decisions.
  • ↳ Colposcopy findings may indicate need for treatment.
  • ↳ Treatment Options:
  • ↳ Treatment Options:
  • ↳ Local Destructive Methods: Cryosurgery: Freezing abnormal tissue. Electrocoagulation: Using heat from electrical current. Laser Ablation: Using a laser to destroy abnormal cells. Excisional Treatments: LEEP/LLETZ: Removing abnormal tissue with a wire loop electrode. (Option C) Cone Biopsy: Removing a cone-shaped piece of tissue from the cervix.
  • ↳ Local Destructive Methods: Cryosurgery: Freezing abnormal tissue. Electrocoagulation: Using heat from electrical current. Laser Ablation: Using a laser to destroy abnormal cells.
  • ↳ Local Destructive Methods:
  • ↳ Cryosurgery: Freezing abnormal tissue. Electrocoagulation: Using heat from electrical current. Laser Ablation: Using a laser to destroy abnormal cells.
  • ↳ Cryosurgery: Freezing abnormal tissue.
  • ↳ Cryosurgery:
  • ↳ Electrocoagulation: Using heat from electrical current.
  • ↳ Electrocoagulation:
  • ↳ Laser Ablation: Using a laser to destroy abnormal cells.
  • ↳ Laser Ablation:
  • ↳ Excisional Treatments: LEEP/LLETZ: Removing abnormal tissue with a wire loop electrode. (Option C) Cone Biopsy: Removing a cone-shaped piece of tissue from the cervix.
  • ↳ Excisional Treatments:
  • ↳ LEEP/LLETZ: Removing abnormal tissue with a wire loop electrode. (Option C) Cone Biopsy: Removing a cone-shaped piece of tissue from the cervix.
  • ↳ LEEP/LLETZ: Removing abnormal tissue with a wire loop electrode. (Option C)
  • ↳ LEEP/LLETZ:
  • ↳ (Option C)
  • ↳ Cone Biopsy: Removing a cone-shaped piece of tissue from the cervix.
  • ↳ Cone Biopsy:
  • ↳ Cryoablation Local destructive treatment for CIN using freeze-thaw-freeze technique. Instrument: Metal probe uses nitrous oxide to freeze tissue (cryonecrosis). Mechanism: Freezes tissue to 4-5 mm depth using agents like CO2 (-60°C), Freon (-60°C), Nitrous Oxide (-80°C). Indications for Cryoablation: Small cervical lesions. Entirely ectocervical lesions and visible SCJ. Smooth cervical surface without deep crevices. Circumferential length adequate to prevent vaginal wall thermal damage. Advantages: Inexpensive, well-tolerated, painless OP procedure (lasts over 9 mins) Exclusions: Not for previously treated patients, glandular abnormalities, or AIS. Disadvantages: Profuse discharge for 7-10 days post-procedure. Challenges in subsequent colposcopy screenings due to junction retraction.
  • ↳ Cryoablation

  • ↳ Cryoablation

Mechanism: Freezes tissue to 4-5 mm depth using agents like CO2 (-60°C), Freon (-60°C), Nitrous Oxide (-80°C). Indications for Cryoablation: Small cervical lesions. Entirely ectocervical lesions and visible SCJ. Smooth cervical surface without deep crevices. Circumferential length adequate to prevent vaginal wall thermal damage. Advantages: Inexpensive, well-tolerated, painless OP procedure (lasts over 9 mins) Exclusions: Not for previously treated patients, glandular abnormalities, or AIS. Disadvantages: Profuse discharge for 7-10 days post-procedure. Challenges in subsequent colposcopy screenings due to junction retraction.
  • ↳ Local destructive treatment for CIN using freeze-thaw-freeze technique. Instrument: Metal probe uses nitrous oxide to freeze tissue (cryonecrosis). Mechanism: Freezes tissue to 4-5 mm depth using agents like CO2 (-60°C), Freon (-60°C), Nitrous Oxide (-80°C). Indications for Cryoablation: Small cervical lesions. Entirely ectocervical lesions and visible SCJ. Smooth cervical surface without deep crevices. Circumferential length adequate to prevent vaginal wall thermal damage. Advantages: Inexpensive, well-tolerated, painless OP procedure (lasts over 9 mins) Exclusions: Not for previously treated patients, glandular abnormalities, or AIS. Disadvantages: Profuse discharge for 7-10 days post-procedure. Challenges in subsequent colposcopy screenings due to junction retraction.
  • ↳ Local destructive treatment for CIN using freeze-thaw-freeze technique. Instrument: Metal probe uses nitrous oxide to freeze tissue (cryonecrosis). Mechanism: Freezes tissue to 4-5 mm depth using agents like CO2 (-60°C), Freon (-60°C), Nitrous Oxide (-80°C). Indications for Cryoablation: Small cervical lesions. Entirely ectocervical lesions and visible SCJ. Smooth cervical surface without deep crevices. Circumferential length adequate to prevent vaginal wall thermal damage. Advantages: Inexpensive, well-tolerated, painless OP procedure (lasts over 9 mins) Exclusions: Not for previously treated patients, glandular abnormalities, or AIS. Disadvantages: Profuse discharge for 7-10 days post-procedure. Challenges in subsequent colposcopy screenings due to junction retraction.
  • ↳ Local destructive treatment for CIN using freeze-thaw-freeze technique.
  • ↳ Instrument: Metal probe uses nitrous oxide to freeze tissue (cryonecrosis).
  • ↳ Instrument:
  • ↳ Mechanism: Freezes tissue to 4-5 mm depth using agents like CO2 (-60°C), Freon (-60°C), Nitrous Oxide (-80°C).
  • ↳ Mechanism:
  • ↳ Indications for Cryoablation: Small cervical lesions. Entirely ectocervical lesions and visible SCJ. Smooth cervical surface without deep crevices. Circumferential length adequate to prevent vaginal wall thermal damage.
  • ↳ Indications for Cryoablation:
  • ↳ Small cervical lesions. Entirely ectocervical lesions and visible SCJ. Smooth cervical surface without deep crevices. Circumferential length adequate to prevent vaginal wall thermal damage.
  • ↳ Small cervical lesions.
  • ↳ Entirely ectocervical lesions and visible SCJ.
  • ↳ Smooth cervical surface without deep crevices.
  • ↳ Circumferential length adequate to prevent vaginal wall thermal damage.
  • ↳ Advantages: Inexpensive, well-tolerated, painless OP procedure (lasts over 9 mins)
  • ↳ Advantages:
  • ↳ Exclusions: Not for previously treated patients, glandular abnormalities, or AIS.
  • ↳ Exclusions:
  • ↳ Disadvantages: Profuse discharge for 7-10 days post-procedure. Challenges in subsequent colposcopy screenings due to junction retraction.
  • ↳ Disadvantages:
  • ↳ Profuse discharge for 7-10 days post-procedure. Challenges in subsequent colposcopy screenings due to junction retraction.
  • ↳ Profuse discharge for 7-10 days post-procedure.
  • ↳ Challenges in subsequent colposcopy screenings due to junction retraction.
  • ↳ P16 immunochemistry testing (Option A) detects p16 protein overexpression associated with high-risk HPV infections and cervical dysplasia. It helps differentiate between LSIL and HSIL but does not treat CIN 1.
  • ↳ P16 immunochemistry testing (Option A)

Cryoablation
  • Local destructive treatment for CIN using freeze-thaw-freeze technique.
  • Instrument: Metal probe uses nitrous oxide to freeze tissue (cryonecrosis).
  • Mechanism: Freezes tissue to 4-5 mm depth using agents like CO2 (-60°C), Freon (-60°C), Nitrous Oxide (-80°C).
  • Indications for Cryoablation:
    • Small cervical lesions.
    • Entirely ectocervical lesions and visible SCJ.
    • Smooth cervical surface without deep crevices.
    • Circumferential length adequate to prevent vaginal wall thermal damage.
  • Advantages: Inexpensive, well-tolerated, painless OP procedure (lasts over 9 mins)
  • Exclusions: Not for previously treated patients, glandular abnormalities, or AIS.
  • Disadvantages:
    • Profuse discharge for 7-10 days post-procedure.
    • Challenges in subsequent colposcopy screenings due to junction retraction.

questions.text: A 25 y/o female presents for her annual examination. Her Pap smear results show atypical squamous cells, and cannot rule out high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (ASC-H). What is the next best step in management?
questions.explanation:
Bethesda Classification

Inference

Management

Negative for Intraepithelial Lesion or Malignancy (NILM)

Normal smear
  • Aged 21-29 - Cytology every 3 years
  • Aged 30-65- Cytology every 3 years or co-testing every 5 years

Atypical Squamous Cells of Undetermined Significance (ASC-US)

Abnormal squamous cells but do not meet the criteria for a squamous intraepithelial lesion
  • Followed by HPV co-test
  • If Positive HPV: Colposcopy.
  • If Negative HPV: Repeat co-test after 3 years.
  • If HPV Testing NOT done: Repeat cytology in 1 year; colposcopy if abnormal

Atypical Squamous Cells (ASC-H)

Indicates a higher risk of precancerous or cancerous cells and necessitates further investigation to rule out more serious conditions.
  • Colposcopy with biopsy. (Option B)
  • HPV testing may be considered in conjunction with the colposcopy.

LSIL

Mildly abnormal cells, changes attributable to HPV

Women ≥25 Years

  • Colposcopy.
  • If HPV-negative: Repeat cotesting in 1 year.

Women 21–24 Years

  • Repeat cytology at 12 and 24 months (follow ASC-US guidelines).

Pregnant Women

  • Manage as non-pregnant.
  • No ECC; defer colposcopy until 6 weeks postpartum if needed.

Postmenopausal Women

  • Reflex HPV, repeat Pap (6 & 12 months), or colposcopy.
  • If HPV-negative/no CIN: Repeat in 12 months.
  • If HPV-positive/ASC or worse: Colposcopy.
  • Routine screening after 2 negative cytology results.

High-grade Squamous Intraepithelial Lesion (HSIL)

Suggests a high-grade precancerous lesion.

Colposcopy with biopsy.

Adenocarcinoma In Situ (AIS)

Indicates the presence of precancerous glandular cells.

Colposcopy with biopsy.

Malignant Cells

Indicates the presence of cancerous cells.
  • Colposcopy with biopsy.
  • Endocervical curettage is avoided during pregnancy to prevent uterine irritation, bleeding, or potential harm to the developing fetus.
  • If colposcopy-directed biopsy fails to confirm a malignancy, diagnostic conization is done.

questions.text: A 30 Y/o woman visits her gynecologist for a routine Pap smear. Her Pap smear results come back abnormal, showing high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesions (HSIL). Further testing reveals that she is positive for HPV types 16 and 18. Which of the following most appropriately describes the role of HPV in cervical cancer?

options.label: A
options.text: Produces toxins that cause uncontrolled cell proliferation

options.label: C
options.text: Stimulation of immune system to attack normal cervical cells

options.label: D
options.text: Causing chronic inflammation leading to cancer

questions.correct_answer: B. Suppression of tumor suppressor genes
questions.explanation:
E6

Binds to p53 tumor suppressor protein

E7

Binds to retinoblastoma (Rb) tumor suppressor protein

questions.text: A 30 Y/o woman presents to her gynecologist for a routine Pap smear. The results show abnormal cells and a subsequent colposcopy with biopsy reveals cervical intraepithelial neoplasia involving lower 1/3rd to 2/3rd of the thickness of the cervical epithelium. Which of the following is the Bethesda classification for the patient?
questions.correct_answer: C. High grade squamous intraepithelial lesion
questions.explanation:
Area Involved

HPE

Bethesda classification

Regression %

Progression %

thickness of cervical epithelium

CIN 1

Low grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (LSIL)(Option B)

60%

30%

Lower 1/3rd to 2/3rd thickness of cervical epithelium

CIN 2

High grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL)(Option C)

40%

35%

>lower 2/3rd thickness of cervical epithelium

CIN 3

32%

50%

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding metaplastic and dysplastic changes in the cervix?

options.label: A
options.text: Both metaplasia and dysplasia are pathologic changes

options.label: B
options.text: Metaplasia is physiological change, whereas dysplasia is pathological

options.label: C
options.text: Metaplasia is pathological change, whereas dysplasia is physiological

options.label: D
options.text: Both metaplasia and dysplasia are physiological changes

questions.correct_answer: B. Metaplasia is physiological change, whereas dysplasia is pathological

questions.text: A 55-year-old postmenopausal woman undergoes colposcopy for an abnormal Pap smear result. During the examination, the gynecologist notices that the squamocolumnar junction has receded into the endocervical canal, and the inner margin is not entirely seen. Which type of transformation zone is observed in this woman?
questions.explanation:
Type

Seen in

Appearance

Type 1 (Option A)
  • Adolescence
  • Pregnancy 
  • OCPs

The entire TZ is visible and is only ectocervical

 


 

Type 2 (Option B)

 Premenopausal

The entire TZ is visible but has some endocervical component

 

Type 3 (Option C)
  • Menopause
  • Progestin only pills

The TZ is partially visible and extends into endocervix

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman has presented with abdominal distension and discomfort for the past few months. On examination, there is bilateral pelvic tenderness with a palpable pelvic mass. Ultrasound confirms a large cystic lesion 8-10 cm in the right ovary with irregular solid areas. Serum CA-125 levels are elevated. Which of the following epithelial ovarian tumors is most likely to present with the described clinical findings?
questions.explanation:
Type of Epithelial Ovarian Tumor

Characteristics

Clinical Presentation

Serous Tumors

Serous Cystadenoma: Benign, unilateral, cystic spaces with serous epithelium.

Large cystic mass, unilateral.
 

Serous Cystadenocarcinoma: Malignant, often bilateral, cystic and solid components.

Bilateral involvement in 30%, elevated CA-125.

Mucinous Tumors

Mucinous Cystadenoma (Option A): Benign, unilateral, filled with mucinous fluid.

Large, unilateral mass.
 

Mucinous Cystadenocarcinoma: Malignant, unilateral, mucinous epithelial lining.

May rupture and spread to the peritoneum.

Endometrioid Tumors

Endometrioid Carcinoma (Option C): Arises from endometrial-like tissue, solid and cystic.

Solid and cystic components, associated with endometriosis.

Clear Cell Tumors

Clear Cell Carcinoma: Clear cytoplasm due to glycogen accumulation.

Advanced stage, associated with endometriosis.

Brenner Tumors (Transitional Cell)

Brenner Tumor (Option D): Transitional epithelial cells resembling urinary tract epithelium.

Rare, usually benign.

Ovarian Tumor

Epithelial

Sex cord-stromal

Germ cell
  • Serous
  • Mucinous
  • Endometroid
  • Clear cell
  • Brenner
  • Granulosa cell
  • Thecoma
  • Fibroma
  • Sertoli - Leydig
  • Gynandroblastoma
  • Teratoma
  • Dysgerminoma
  • Endodermal sinus tumor
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Choriocarcinoma
  • Gonadoblastoma
  • Mixed germ cell

questions.text: A 55-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with abdominal distension and discomfort. Transvaginal ultrasound confirms a complex ovarian mass. CA-125 levels are elevated. Further imaging and biopsy confirm the diagnosis of high-grade serous ovarian carcinoma. She undergoes primary debulking surgery, and the tumor is staged as advanced (Stage III) disease. Which of the following chemotherapy regimens is most appropriate as the first-line adjuvant treatment for this patient following her surgery?
Which of the following statements is true about ovarian masses in pregnancy?

options.label: A
options.text: Malignant ovarian tumors require surgery immediately after pregnancy

options.label: B
options.text: Benign ovarian tumors are removed preferably in the first trimester

options.label: C
options.text: Corpus luteum cyst must be operated before the 12th week of gestation

questions.text: A 50-year-old postmenopausal woman, non-obese, presents with complaints of irregular vaginal bleeding over the past two months. She reports no significant medical history except for using unopposed estrogen hormone replacement therapy (HRT) for the last five years Which condition, characterized by elevated estrogen levels alone, increases her risk of developing endometrial cancer?
questions.explanation:
Endometrial Carcinoma

Risk factors

Protective factors

  • Age (>50 yrs)
  • Obesity
  • Estrogen exposure
  • Nulliparity
  • Tamoxifen
  • Family history
    • Lynch syndrome
    • BRCA1 & BRCA2 mutations
  • Diabetes
  • Hypertension
  • Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)
  • Oral contraceptives
  • Pregnancy and childbirth
  • Regular exercise
  • Healthy weight management
  • LNS-IUS

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her mother with complaints of breast development and vaginal bleeding. An ultrasound reveals a mixed solid and cystic ovarian mass measuring 5 cm. Laboratory tests show elevated levels of inhibin B and estradiol. The HPE slide is given below:- What is the next step in the management of the patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Observation and follow-up with repeat ultrasound

options.label: B
options.text: Hormonal therapy to manage precocious puberty

options.label: D
options.text: Chemotherapy to reduce the size of the tumor

questions.explanation:
A. Granulosa Cell Tumors

Incidence

  • 70% of all ovarian SCSTs are granulosa cell tumors

  • 2% of all ovarian neoplasms

Types

  • Adult form (95%)

  • Juvenile form (5%)

Characteristics

  • Slow growing

  • Solid or cystic or mixed

  • Cut section shows yellow/orange due to lipid content

HPE Appearance

  • Round/polygonal cells with granular eosinophilic cytoplasm

  • Coffee bean nuclei

  • Call-Exner bodies (Pathognomonic)

 

Hormonal Activity & Markers

  • Secrete inhibin B, estrogen, and AMH

Clinical Features

  • Prior to puberty: Precocious puberty

  • Childbearing period: Abnormal uterine bleeding

  • Postmenopausal: Bleeding often with endometrial hyperplasia or adenocarcinoma

Prognosis

  • Good overall prognosis

  • 5-year survival rate for stage I disease is about 95%

B. Theca Cell Tumors

Presentation

Presents after Menopause

Characteristics

Solid yellow tumor containing lipoid material

Hormonal Activity & Markers

Estrogen

Clinical Features

Estrogenic (causes post-menopausal bleed)

Usually Benign

C. Sertoli Leydig Tumors / Arrhenoblastomas

Incidence

0.5% of all ovarian tumours, 5% of all SCST’s

Characteristics

Small, solid, unilateral tumor and on HPE Reinke crystals are pathognomonic.

Hormonal Activity & Markers

Androgens, Inhibin, AFP

Clinical Features

  • Hirsutism (Male pattern baldness, excessive hair growth) - Reversible

  • Virilization (Hoarseness, Breast atrophy, Clitoromegaly) - Permanent

  • Oligomenorrhea to Amenorrhea

questions.text: Which of the following tumors is not associated with Meig's syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Meig's Syndrome

Pseudomeig's Syndrome

Ascites

Ascites

Pleural Effusion

Pleural Effusion

Ovarian fibroma (Option A), thecoma (Option B), granulosa cell tumor (Option C)

Brenner Tumour, Leiomyoma (MC) (Option D), Struma ovarii, mucinous cystadenoma, teratomas

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents with a large adnexal mass detected on a routine pelvic examination. She complains of intermittent pelvic pain and bloating over the past few months. Ultrasound imaging reveals a 10 cm complex ovarian mass diagnosed as germ cell tumor. What is the most appropriate surgical approach in this scenario?

options.label: A
options.text: Total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy

options.label: B
options.text: Unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy with staging and preservation of the contralateral ovary and uterus

options.label: C
options.text: Bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy with omentectomy and lymph node dissection

options.label: D
options.text: Laparoscopic cystectomy to remove only the cystic portion of the mass

questions.correct_answer: B. Unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy with staging and preservation of the contralateral ovary and uterus

questions.text: Which of the following statements about HE4 and the Risk of Ovarian Malignancy Algorithm (ROMA) score is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: HE4 is a marker that is specific for mucinous ovarian cancer.

options.label: B
options.text: The ROMA score combines HE4 and CA-125 levels with menopausal status to assess the risk of ovarian cancer.

options.label: C
options.text: HE4 is only useful in the diagnosis of ovarian cancer in postmenopausal women.

options.label: D
options.text: The ROMA score is primarily used to predict the risk of breast cancer.

questions.correct_answer: B. The ROMA score combines HE4 and CA-125 levels with menopausal status to assess the risk of ovarian cancer.
questions.explanation:
Pre-menopausal Predictive Index (PI): 12 + 2.38 x LN(HE4) + 0.0626 x LN (CA-125)

Post-menopausal Predictive Index (PI): 8.09 + 1.04 x LN(HE4) + 0.732 x LN (CA-125)

ROMA(%): 100 X Exp PI/ (1 + Exp PI)

ROMAcut-off: 7.4% for premenopausal women

25.3% postmenopausal women

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with persistent abdominal bloating, early fullness, and lower abdominal pain for the past three months. On physical examination, a firm, non-tender mass is palpated in the right lower abdomen. A transvaginal ultrasound identifies a 7 cm complex ovarian mass with both cystic and solid components, along with septations. Her serum CA-125 level is elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following factors is most commonly associated with the development of ovarian epithelial surface tumors?

options.label: C
options.text: High parity and use of oral contraceptives

options.label: D
options.text: Familial history of BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations

questions.correct_answer: D. Familial history of BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations
questions.explanation:
Risk Factors for Ovarian Epithelial Tumors

Protective factors for ovarian cancer

Age between 45 and 60 years

Physical exercise

Nulliparous or of low parity (higher estrogen exposure)

Related to ovulation-anovulation (multiparity, OCP, breastfeeding) (Option C)

Women with previous PCOS, or on Tamoxifen (higher estrogen exposure)

Surgeries- hysterectomy, tubal ligation, salpingectomy

High-calorie, High-fat diet (Higher estrogen exposure)

  

Genetic predisposition BRCA-1 and BRCA-2 gene mutation (Option D)

Late menopause and early menarche (high estrogen exposure)

Family history of breast and Gastrointestinal cancer

Multiple cycles of ovulation induction

Scars

↑ Scars → Epithelium→ Overhealing → Epithelial ovarian CA

Asbestos Exposure

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with abnormal uterine bleeding. Endometrial biopsy reveals a histopathological diagnosis of endometrial carcinoma. Further evaluation shows that the tumor predominantly comprises glands with irregular architecture, cytologic atypia, and mitotic activity. What histopathological type of endometrial cancer does this description most likely correspond to?
questions.explanation:
Endometrioid Carcinoma

Serous carcinoma

Clear cell carcinoma

HPE Image

Features
  • Tubular glands with back to back pattern
  • Eosinophilic keratin deposition
  • May demonstrate cytological atypia (Option A)
  • Complex papillae
  • Free cells with significant cytological atypia
  • (Option B)
  • Hobnail cells with clear or eosinophilic cytoplasm.
  • Nuclear Atypia seen
  • (Option C)

Prognosis
  • Favourable
  • Poorer
  • Poorer

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with complaints of persistent vulvar itching and a non-healing lesion on her vulva. On PE, a thickened, whitish plaque and ulceration are noted on the labia majora. Histopathology reveals atypical squamous cells confined to the epithelium with marked basal atypia and abnormal keratinisation as shown below. Which of the following is the patient suffering from?
questions.explanation:
Normal vulva

  • Lined by stratified squamous epithelium

Vulvar LSIL
  • Seen in younger women (option B)
  • Etiology: HPV effect
  • Flat lesions with condyloma
  • Self limited, not precancerous

Histology:

 

 

  • Mild atypical cells in the lower third of epithelium
  • Koilocytes in the upper layer

Vulval HSIL
  • Formerly called usual VIN (option A&C)
  • Seen in younger women
  • Etiology: HPV infection, STDs, immunosuppression, smoking
  • Multicentric & multifocal disease
  • Precancerous condition

Histology:

 

 

  • Atypical squamous cells in all layers of epithelium
  • Extensive parakeratosis
  • Koilocytic changes in the upper layer.

Differentiated VIN
  • Seen in older, postmenopausal women (option D)
  • Etiology: Lichen sclerosus and other chronic dermatological conditions
  • Unicentric and unifocal disease
  • Precancerous condition

Histology:

 

 

  • Prominent nucleoli
  • Basal atypia with acanthosis, dyskeratosis

Vulvar LSIL
  • Self-limited condition.
  • Not treated unless symptomatic.

Vulvar HSIL and differentiated VIN
  • Precancerous conditions.
  • All lesions should be treated.
  • Treatment options:
  • Wide local excision
  • Laser ablation
  • Topical 5-FU or imiquimod

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman has been diagnosed with SCC arising from the Bartholin gland following a biopsy after she presented with complaints of unilateral swelling in the vulvar area. Which of the following is an indication for bartholin gland biopsy?

options.label: C
options.text: Solid mass arising from Bartholin gland

questions.explanation:
Bartholin gland carcinoma
  • Maybe adenocarcinomas, SCC, or transitional cell carcinoma

Clinical features
  • Painless vulval mass
  • Perineal pain
  • Dyspareunia
  • Spreads to ischiorectal fossa and pelvic nodes

Investigations
  • MRI
  • Bartholin biopsy: Indications include,
    • Woman over 40 years
    • Recurrent cyst/abscess
    • All solid masses

Treatment
  • Radical vulvectomy + Ipsilateral/bilateral groin dissection
  • Pre/post-operative chemoradiation

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents with a 3 cm ulcerated lesion on the left labia majora. Biopsy confirms invasive squamous cell carcinoma. Physical examination reveals two palpable, mobile lymph nodes in the left groin, each measuring approximately 1 mm in diameter. What is the most likely FIGO stage of her vulvar cancer?
questions.explanation:
Staging of Invasive Vulvar Cancer

Stage 1

Limited to vulva.

1a

Tumor ≤ 2 cm, stromal invasion ≤ 1 mm, no nodal metastasis (Option A)

1b

Tumor > 2 cm, stromal invasion > 1 mm with negative nodes (Option B)

Stage II

Tumor of any size with extension to adjacent perineal structures (1/3 lower urethra, 1/3 lower vagina, anus) with negative nodes

Stage III

Tumor of any size with extension to upper ⅔ vagina, upper ⅔ urethra, bladder, or rectum.

IIIa

Regional LN ≤ 5 mm (Option C)

IIIb

Regional LN > 5 mm

IIIc

Regional LN with extracapsular spread.

Stage IV

  

IVa

Tumor invades any of the following:

  1. upper urethral and/or vaginal mucosa, bladder mucosa, rectal mucosa, or fixed to the pelvic bone, or
  2. Fixed or ulcerated inguinofemoral lymph nodes. (Option D)

IVb

Distant metastasis, including pelvic lymph nodes

questions.text: Which of the following is a contraindication of sentinel lymph node biopsy in vulvar cancer?

options.label: A
options.text: Tumor is located on the labia majora.

options.label: B
options.text: Tumor is smaller than 4 cm in diameter.

options.label: C
options.text: Tumor invades > 1 mm into the stroma.

questions.correct_answer: D. Clinically suspicious groin lymph nodes.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Vulval Intraepithelial Neoplasia (VIN)?

options.label: A
options.text: It is primarily associated with bacterial infection.

options.label: C
options.text: HPV infection is not associated with VIN.

options.label: D
options.text: >50% of cases progress into vulvar cancer.

questions.correct_answer: B. Smoking is an etiological factor.
questions.explanation:
Etiology
  • HPV infection (HPV DNA found in 80% VIN lesions) (Option C)

→ Most common serotype - HPV 16

  • Other STDs - HSV, HIV
  • Cigarette smoking (Option B)
  • Immunosuppression
  • Lichen sclerosus or other chronic dermatological conditions

Classification
  • Vulvar LSIL: Self-limited, not precancerous
  • Vulvar HSIL (formerly called Usual VIN): Multicentric and multifocal disease
  • Differentiated VIN: Precursor to most vulvar SCC

Clinical features
  • The majority of patients are asymptomatic
  • Non-specific symptoms like pruritus, burning and pain are seen in some patients.

HSIL= high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion; LSIL= low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion
